title: Home
text:
Internship Overview
During my internship, I worked on several projects related to sea ice data analysis:

Milestone 1: Learned to access and manipulate satellite data
Milestone 2: Conducted sea ice concentration analysis and visualized spatial-temporal data
Milestone 3: Analyzed sea ice anomalies and trends in the Arctic
Milestone 4: Developed a machine learning model to predict sea ice extent

title: Home
text:
Key Skills and Tools
This internship allowed me to work with:

Programming: Python, xarray, NumPy, Pandas
Data Visualization: Matplotlib, Seaborn
Machine Learning: LSTM, Attention Mechanism
Datasets: Sea Ice Concentration data from NOAA/NSIDC, atmospheric and oceanic datasets

title: Home
text:
Final Thoughts
This internship has been an incredible learning experience, deepening my understanding of climate science and machine learning applications. I look forward to further contributing to the field of satellite data analysis in the future.

title: Milestone 4: Machine Learning for Sea Ice Prediction
text:
Key Objectives

Develop an LSTM-based model to predict monthly sea ice extent
Incorporate sea ice thickness data into the model
Evaluate the performance of the model on historical data

title: Milestone 4: Machine Learning for Sea Ice Prediction
text:
Tasks and Methods

Preprocessed the sea ice thickness data and merged it with other predictors
Implemented an LSTM network with an attention mechanism for better feature selection
Evaluated the model’s performance on a holdout dataset

title: Milestone 4: Machine Learning for Sea Ice Prediction
text:

Successfully developed and trained the LSTM model to predict sea ice extent with a 1-month lead time
The model captured significant trends in sea ice extent, although further tuning is needed for improved accuracy.

title: About Me: Tien Ly
text:
Hello, my name is Tien Ly, and I am passionate about climate change and polar research. My work integrates bioinformatics, machine learning, and climate science, allowing me to tackle complex environmental challenges. With a deep interest in using data-driven approaches to understand the impacts of climate change, I aim to contribute to meaningful research that addresses pressing global issues. You can explore my full resume, which includes my contact information, for more details on my experience and background.
See my resume

Education
I am currently pursuing a Master of Science in Bioinformatics at San Jose State University (2023–2025), where I maintain a 4.0 GPA. Prior to this, I earned a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science from University of California, Davis (2019–2022), graduating with a 3.98 GPA. My coursework includes a blend of computer science and life sciences, with specializations in data structures, machine learning, and bioinformatics.


Experience
With a strong foundation in both bioinformatics and programming, I have held roles as a Graduate Student Researcher at SJSU Castillo Vardaro Molecular Ecology Lab, where I focus on whole-genome sequencing to identify adaptation signals related to climate change. My work involves developing bioinformatics pipelines for high-throughput sequencing data.
Previously, as a Bioinformatics Programmer at UC Davis Genomic Variation Laboratory, I optimized bioinformatics workflows and developed scripts to analyze next-generation sequencing (NGS) data, improving species detection and research efficiency.


Skills
My technical skill set includes:

Programming Languages: Python, R, C/C++, JavaScript, HTML/CSS, SQL
Tools: Git/GitHub, Jupyter Notebook, Visual Studio Code, NCBI databases, RStudio
Frameworks: Node.js, React
Operating Systems: Linux, macOS, Windows



Projects
I have completed various projects that demonstrate my ability to apply machine learning and bioinformatics techniques, including:

SVM Prediction of BRAF V600E Inhibitors: Developed a highly accurate (98%) SVM model for cancer drug discovery
Benchmarking Genome Assemblers: Assessed assembly tools for microbial genomes, utilizing high-throughput sequencing data and visualization techniques

title: Milestone 3: Sea Ice Concentration Trends and Anomalies
text: In this milestone, I focused on analyzing sea ice concentration anomalies and trends for 2023 compared to a climatological baseline. This involved statistical analysis and visualization of anomalies.

title: Milestone 3: Sea Ice Concentration Trends and Anomalies
text: In this milestone, I focused on analyzing sea ice concentration anomalies and trends for 2023 compared to a climatological baseline. This involved statistical analysis and visualization of anomalies.

title: Milestone 3: Sea Ice Concentration Trends and Anomalies
text:
Key Objectives

Compare 2023 sea ice concentration with the 2006-2020 climatology
Identify and visualize significant anomalies and trends for 2023
Perform a statistical analysis to detect significant changes

title: Milestone 3: Sea Ice Concentration Trends and Anomalies
text:
Tasks and Methods

Computed weekly climatology from daily data (2006-2020)
Identified weeks with significant anomalies and visualized them using polar projection maps
Conducted the Mann-Kendall test to determine trends

title: Milestone 3: Sea Ice Concentration Trends and Anomalies
text:
Results and Findings

Discovered significant negative anomalies in certain weeks, indicating reduced sea ice extent compared to the climatology
Visualized the largest anomalies in sea ice concentration using Cartopy

title: Milestone 3: Sea Ice Concentration Trends and Anomalies
text:
Challenges and Learnings

Implementing the Mann-Kendall test for trend detection was a new learning experience
Mapping anomalies clearly required fine-tuning of visualization parameters

title: Milestone 3: Sea Ice Concentration Trends and Anomalies
text:
Next Steps

Develop a machine learning model to predict sea ice extent in Milestone 4
